message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical findings described are consistent with breast cancer. The presence of subareolar microcalcifications on mammography is highly suggestive of invasive ductal carcinoma. Options (A) and (C) are less likely as they usually do not present with nipple involvement. Medullary carcinoma (D) is typically associated with younger patients and may have a more favorable prognosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings suggest breast cancer, and the presence of a palpable mass and lymphadenopathy indicates an invasive carcinoma rather than ductal carcinoma in situ. While lobular carcinoma can present with a skin rash, it is less likely to present with microcalcifications on mammogram. Medullary carcinoma is rare and typically affects younger patients with a family history of breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image of the rash, subareolar microcalcifications, and lymphadenopathy in the right axilla all suggest breast cancer. Among the options, invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer. Ductal carcinoma in situ is non-invasive, invasive lobular carcinoma is less common, and medullary carcinoma is a rare type of breast cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a persistent rash, subareolar microcalcifications, palpable lymphadenopathy, and a mass under the areola suggest invasive ductal carcinoma. Ductal carcinoma in situ does not show a palpable mass or lymphadenopathy. Invasive lobular carcinoma and medullary carcinoma do not present with subareolar microcalcifications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The persistent rash, subareolar microcalcifications, and palpable mass suggest invasive ductal carcinoma, which is the most common type of breast cancer. Ductal carcinoma in situ does not present with a mass or lymphadenopathy, while invasive lobular carcinoma is less likely to present with microcalcifications on mammogram. Medullary carcinoma typically presents in younger patients and is less commonly associated with nipple symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation, including persistent rash on one nipple, palpable mass under the areola, and lymphadenopathy in the axilla, suggests Invasive ductal carcinoma. Microcalcifications found in mammography are also a common feature of invasive ductal carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a persistent rash on the nipple, subareolar microcalcifications on mammogram, and palpable lymphadenopathy in the axilla are highly suggestive of invasive ductal carcinoma. Ductal carcinoma in situ is noninvasive and does not usually present with symptoms. Invasive lobular carcinoma does not typically cause nipple changes or skin rash. Medullary carcinoma presents as a distinct mass with well-defined margins, rather than microcalcifications on mammogram.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the image suggest the most likely diagnosis as Paget’s disease of the breast, which often coexists with invasive breast cancer. The presence of a palpable mass and axillary lymphadenopathy suggests invasive ductal carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of persistent rash, palpable lump, and lymphadenopathy are concerning for breast cancer. The image shows signs of Paget's disease of the nipple, which is often associated with underlying invasive ductal carcinoma. Subareolar microcalcifications on mammogram are also a common finding in invasive ductal carcinoma. Therefore, option (B) is the most likely type of breast cancer in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a persistent rash, subareolar microcalcifications, and palpable lymphadenopathy on the right axilla raises suspicion for breast cancer. Among the options, invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer.
